speaker: ER
transcript: I think I talked to Kristen earlier for a minute, maybe she does or does not about this, but there's a lot of sensors they're putting in cities now just for biological or other sort of terrorist attacks where they're trying to be distributed measurements. Like, couldn't you tap into those kind of systems to get an idea of CO2 measurements for placement and also for optimization of a city-wide system?

annotations.present new idea: ER introduces the idea of using existing city sensors for CO2 measurement and optimization.
annotations.ask clarifying question: ER poses a question about the feasibility of using existing sensor systems for CO2 measurement.

speaker: AP
transcript: So, urban cities, great idea. I totally agree with you. Another thing is people are also looking at direct air capture inside of buildings. There are many other things you can do because inside buildings has a lot higher concentration of CO2 than outside. We are point sources of CO2. In your room, much higher than 410 ppm, right? So people are looking into this. But the reason historically DAC was developed kind of a rural area or non-urban setting is because one of the benefit of DAC is that you can co-locate CO2 storage site with the CO2 capture site so that you can eliminate the transportation between, right? So there's a huge saving of that. So let's say if you have a place for injection of CO2, which is usually not in the city, this is where you want to build, like Iceland, middle of nowhere. So there are pros and cons involved. Those are good questions.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: AP acknowledges ER's idea about using city sensors by saying "great idea" and "I totally agree with you."
annotations.expand on existing idea: AP expands on the idea of urban CO2 capture by discussing direct air capture inside buildings and the historical context of DAC development in rural areas.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: AP supports the idea of direct air capture in buildings by stating that indoor CO2 concentrations are much higher than outside and that people are point sources of CO2.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: AP explains the benefits of co-locating CO2 storage and capture sites in rural areas, eliminating transportation needs and costs.

speaker: KS
transcript: As I understand it, it's also harder to, even though they're designed modularly, it's harder to deploy them modularly because of the energy, the thermal energy requirement. Is that correct? You need a huge source of gas or coal fired waste heat, in order to, well, not waste heat, but heat in order to do the catalytic process. So if you put them in cities and you run it off electricity, it's not as, not nearly as efficient.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: KS explains why it is harder to deploy modularly designed DAC systems, citing the high thermal energy requirement and the lower efficiency of electricity compared to gas or coal-fired heat sources.
annotations.ask_clarifying_question: KS asks for confirmation about the thermal energy requirements for the catalytic process in DAC systems.

speaker: ER
transcript: Well, a lot of cities also have local plants that are doing steam heat or some other source of heat, so it's not necessarily, I mean, yeah, I understand that problem, but there are a lot of cases where it could work.

annotations.expand on existing idea: ER expands on their previous idea of using city sensors for CO2 measurement by suggesting that cities often have local plants that could provide the necessary heat for DAC systems.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: ER supports their idea by pointing out the existence of local plants as a heat source for DAC systems in cities.
annotations.acknowledge contribution: ER acknowledges KS's point about the difficulty of modular deployment due to energy requirements by saying "I understand that problem."

speaker: GM
transcript: Alyssa, once the CO2 is captured, what are the most current approaches then are using for storing it? And what are people thinking about moving forward in that field?

annotations.ask clarifying question: GM asks Alyssa to elaborate on CO2 storage approaches, both current and future, following the discussion on CO2 capture in urban and rural settings.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: GM directly addresses Alyssa, inviting her to share her expertise on CO2 storage after the previous speakers discussed CO2 capture locations.

speaker: AP
transcript: So I will get to Kristen's comments first and I'll go to yours, right? So there's a huge research area for anybody who's working on material side of it. I'm sure you're thinking about it. Until now, when you develop CO2 capture materials, regardless point source or deck, you have to put energy in. So binding energy, pulling it down, you have to put energy back in. That's a regeneration part and that's where you're going to get that energy is very critical for your net carbon sink as well as energy penalty and all that.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: AP acknowledges Kristen's and GM's comments and questions, stating that she will address them.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: AP explains the energy requirements of CO2 capture materials and the regeneration process involved.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: AP supports her explanation by detailing the energy input required for binding and releasing CO2, emphasizing its impact on net carbon sink and energy penalty.

speaker: AP
transcript: Usually, if you're near power producer, you use waste heat because temperature is about 120 to 140 degrees C, it's not hugely high. That's how they got a lot of credit. They're saying, oh, it's free to come along, right? But if you're middle of nowhere, now you have to burn something or create that heat to do that. So that's why all the discussion Kristen is talking about. But at the same time, should we really use heat to regenerate? That's a new question a lot of people are asking. So until now, to provide energy, they're doing either temperature swing or pressure swing or combination. But can we use microwave? Can we use plasma? Can we use radio frequency? There, only thing you have to do is deliver the energy to which is binding onto CO2. That's a material question. Can that be non-thermal? That's a huge question in there. That's one thing a lot of research is going in that direction. Second, Gary's question, right now, economically, the best thing to do is enhanced oil recovery because there is a market for it, for sure.

explain or define term or concept: Explains why waste heat is used by power producers for carbon capture, defining the temperature range and the reason behind its perceived cost-effectiveness.
Defines current regeneration methods as temperature or pressure swings or a combination, and introduces the concept of non-thermal regeneration methods.
Explains that enhanced oil recovery is currently the most economically viable CO2 storage method due to existing market demand.
present new idea: Introduces the idea of using alternative energy sources like microwave, plasma, and radio frequency for regeneration in carbon capture.
Poses the question of whether non-thermal regeneration is possible, suggesting a novel research direction.
ask clarifying question: Questions the current practice of using heat for regeneration, prompting discussion on alternative approaches.
provide supporting evidence: Supports the explanation of waste heat usage with the temperature range (120-140 degrees C) and the rationale behind its perceived cost-effectiveness.
Justifies the current focus on enhanced oil recovery for CO2 storage by citing its economic viability and market demand.
acknowledge contribution: Acknowledges Kristen's earlier comments regarding the challenges of modular deployment and the need for a heat source.
Acknowledges Gary's question about CO2 storage approaches.

speaker: GS
transcript: So I have a question for the group. Is anybody working on materials that would capture CO2 or on like your separation technology like we heard in the keynote?

annotations.ask clarifying question: GS asks if anyone in the group is working on CO2 capture materials or separation technology, seeking information or clarification on current research efforts related to the keynote topic.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: GS directs his question to the entire group, inviting broader participation and input from other members.

speaker: CG
transcript: I'm doing work on electrochemical direct air capture. So materials usually in aqueous solutions.

annotations.present new idea: CG introduces their work on electrochemical direct air capture, a specific approach to DAC not previously discussed in detail.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: CG clarifies that the materials used in their electrochemical direct air capture method are typically in aqueous solutions, explaining a technical aspect of their work.

speaker: FR
transcript: We work on solid materials for CO2 capture, mini sorbent materials.

annotations.present new idea: FR introduces their team's work on solid materials for CO2 capture, which had not been mentioned by previous speakers in this specific context of material science.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: FR supports their team's expertise by specifying the type of materials they work with, i.e. mini sorbent materials, providing evidence of their involvement in the discussed research area.

speaker: VP
transcript: I, I work on mineral carbonation and algae growth and I'm interested to see options for direct capture using algae.

annotations.present new idea: VP introduces their work on mineral carbonation and algae growth for direct air capture, which had not been previously discussed.
annotations.express enthusiasm: VP expresses interest in exploring direct air capture options using algae, indicating enthusiasm for this research area.

speaker: AP
transcript: and conversion, storage, a lot of overlapping fundamental expertise areas. So it's good to put all of you together in a sense so that you can help each other out to advance science. But at the same time, they really play different roles. So when you try to say one or the other, I think we are going to the wrong direction. That's my philosophy.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: AP explains the overlapping fundamental expertise areas and different roles that the group members have.
annotations.propose decision: AP proposes that focusing on one approach over another would be going in the wrong direction, suggesting the group should consider multiple approaches.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: AP gently criticizes the potential for the group to focus too narrowly on one approach, suggesting a broader perspective.
annotations.express alternative decision: AP rejects the implied decision of focusing on a single approach and suggests considering the diverse roles and expertise within the group.

speaker: AP
transcript: Having said that, let's have this discussion because none of us are, including myself, are not atmospheric simulation people. We don't have one, right? How about we think about if you have to put, because all of you are interested in putting deck and conversion together, utilization together. Where is the best place to put it and what are the challenges? Some people are saying let's put it on the platform in the ocean compared to middle of nowhere or even urban system. What are the challenges, opportunities, and questions we need to ask? That might be easier question, don't you think?

annotations.propose decision: AP suggests the group discuss the placement and challenges of combining DAC and conversion/utilization, focusing on location considerations like ocean platforms, remote areas, or urban systems.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: AP clarifies that the group lacks expertise in atmospheric simulation, highlighting the need for external input or alternative approaches.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: AP encourages the group's participation in discussing the optimal placement and associated challenges of DAC and conversion/utilization.
annotations.ask clarifying question: AP asks the group to consider the challenges, opportunities, and relevant questions regarding the placement of DAC and conversion/utilization technologies in different locations.

speaker: GM
transcript: based on what you taught us already, Alyssa, would it make sense to have these decentralized and and spread over multiple locations, not not one specific area?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Gary is asking Alyssa to clarify the optimal placement strategy for direct air capture and CO2 utilization technologies based on her prior explanations.
annotations.acknowledge contribution: Gary begins by acknowledging Alyssa's teaching and expertise on the subject.

speaker: AP
transcript: First of all, I'm not teaching you anything because I have questions than answers. The reason everybody's kind of puzzles is because we don't have answers yet, right? Is it similar to how to distribute renewable energy, right? Is a solar rooftop making huge impact compared to concentrated solar farm? What do you think, right? There's a lot of still debate over that, too. Some people argue that rooftop solar doesn't really mean much for climate change. Some studies show that. I don't know whether it's true or not, right? But it also have big impacts. Solar rooftop solar PV has a huge impact on how public accepts renewable energy regardless what is the overall impact on climate change. So I think it plays a different role.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Alyssa explains the concept of distributed renewable energy and its impact on climate change.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Alyssa asks the group for their opinion on the impact of rooftop solar compared to concentrated solar farms.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Alyssa supports her point about the debate around rooftop solar by mentioning some studies and public acceptance of renewable energy.
annotations.present new idea: Alyssa introduces the idea of comparing the distribution of renewable energy to the distribution of DAC technology.

speaker: AP
transcript: Alyssa

annotations.None: This single word utterance does not fit any of the provided codes related to scientific collaboration and discussion.

speaker: PB
transcript: I have not an answer but a question for you in the context of CO2 conversion or CO2 capture and utilization. So of course, CO2 is a molecule that's at the bottom of the thermodynamic spectrum, right? And converting it into a useful chemical means you input a certain amount of energy and that has a certain carbon cost, if you will, associated with it, right? So in terms of CO2 conversion to value added chemicals, are there chemicals and or processes where you think the possibility of a net reduction in CO2 while accounting for the necessary energy input exists and what are those chemicals in your estimation?

annotations.ask clarifying question: PB asks a clarifying question about the potential for net CO2 reduction when converting CO2 into value-added chemicals, considering the energy input required.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: PB explains the thermodynamic properties of CO2 and the carbon cost associated with its conversion into useful chemicals.

speaker: AP
transcript: Good question. And I think some of you have answers to this, right? Who wants to volunteer?

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Alyssa acknowledges PB's question about CO2 conversion and its carbon cost as a "good question."
annotations.encourage particpatioin: Alyssa encourages the group to participate by asking, "Who wants to volunteer?"

speaker: CG
transcript: I'm doing mostly structure chemical capture.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: CG clarifies their work by specifying it as "structure chemical capture."

speaker: AP
transcript: capture

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Alyssa acknowledges CG's contribution about doing structural chemical capture by repeating the word "capture".

speaker: CG
transcript: I can give you my perspective on it, which is we don't use nearly enough of any of these like resources that we put CO2 in to considerably change the balance of things. Like if we made all our plastic out of CO2, it might account for a couple percent of the CO2 we need to capture. So sequestration is a big part of it as you said. I think something that people haven't thought about in this area though is so you can make valuable chemicals, but you could also make chemicals that are easier to sequester than CO2 itself, which we have a limited capacity for. And I don't think that's really been explored at all. So can you with less energy make something that's much easier to dispose of or be sequestered for a longer period of time than CO2 itself in a super critical state.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: CG provides evidence about the limited impact of using CO2 for resources like plastics and the need for sequestration.
annotations.expand on existing idea: CG expands on the discussion of CO2 conversion by suggesting the creation of chemicals that are easier to sequester than CO2 itself.
annotations.present new idea: CG introduces the idea of creating chemicals easier to sequester than CO2, which hasn't been previously mentioned.
annotations.ask clarifying question: CG asks if it's possible to create more easily sequestered chemicals with less energy.

speaker: AP
transcript: So I'll give you a good example on that. So let's say you're middle of the ocean, middle of really nowhere. So you have a nuclear power because you're on the platform of Navy. You have a huge amount of access energy. So these are the ifs, right? Then you can convert CO2 to carbon, right, pure carbon. And it's a solid form, it'll be very easy to put it away.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: AP provides a hypothetical scenario of converting CO2 to solid carbon using excess energy from a nuclear power source on a Navy platform in the ocean as a supporting example for CG's idea about creating chemicals easier to sequester than CO2.
annotations.expand_on_existing_idea: AP builds upon CG's idea by providing a specific example of a chemical (pure carbon) that is easier to sequester than CO2 in a supercritical state.
annotations.explain_or_define_term_or_concept: AP explains the concept of converting CO2 into a more easily sequesterable form, solid carbon, using excess energy from a hypothetical nuclear power source on a Navy platform.
